title: POLITICO Playbook: What Republicans want on impeachment
text:
POLITICO Playbook: What Republicans want on impeachment Presented by

House Minority Whip Steve Scalise (R-La.) and other House Republicans speak to reporters on Wednesday, Oct. 23. | Patrick Semansky/AP Photo

DRIVING THE DAY

IT’S PRETTY SAFE TO SAY THAT HOUSE REPUBLICANS have decided to spend the vast majority of their time focusing on their belief that Democrats are conducting a patently unfair impeachment process. That message echoes from the halls of the Capitol -- where Reps. JIM JORDAN, MARK MEADOWS and company say it on repeat -- to the president’s Twitter account to Secretary of State MIKE POMPEO’S plane, where he griped about it to us last week.

IT’S ALSO PRETTY SAFE TO SAY THAT this is a ploy, and a play for public sympathy. Many of the Republicans involved in these goofball antics -- busting into a secure facility, and even making a phone call from inside of it -- will privately concede that. It’s a fine way for a quick headline, a nice way to appease President DONALD TRUMP, and for the slice of the electorate that’s overly concerned about process, perhaps this is a useful tool.

BUT REPUBLICANS WILL SOON FACE a new reality: The impeachment process will move to a more public phase. And at that point, their stand-outside-a-closed-door-for-cameras shtick will no longer work.

SO, WHAT’S NEXT? It’s a bit tough to predict, because we don’t know what the process will look like. There are a bunch of decisions Democrats have to make before TRUMP’S defenders figure out how to best try to defend the president. For example, at this moment, there are four committees involved in impeachment. How do Democrats decide which one/ones get to prosecute the case?

WE SPOKE TO some of the top Republicans in the House to see how they view the next stage of the fight.

-- WITNESSES: REPUBLICANS have wanted to issue subpoenas in closed hearings, and they say when the process goes public, they want to be able to present their side of the case on behalf of the president. MEADOWS (R-N.C.): “I think if it’s fair to Trump it would be the ability to have other witnesses give conflicting or counter testimony, and I’d probably use the word conflicting rather than cross-examining.”

“What we’ve found with six witnesses so far is that there are six different opinions on what happened and why it happened and it’s probably better to view that through the lens of journalists and the American people rather than a partisan lens that wants to see a guilty or acquittal just based on politics.”

-- IN THE DARK … We reminded Rep. LEE ZELDIN (R-N.Y.) that a few dozen Republicans are present at each deposition. He made this point about those who are not: “I still appreciate and understand the frustration of [a] member who is in the dark who is getting all these questions substantively from constituents and local media and they have no idea how to answer those questions because they don’t know what’s happening behind closed doors.”

-- FWIW: Zeldin says he would like all the transcripts released to the public at this point. He says Democrats are moving in the other direction, and aides are monitoring lawmakers if they ask to review the material in the SCIF.

BUT HERE’S THE KEY QUOTE, courtesy of MEADOWS: “Democrats are going to get a report from the Democrats, Republicans are going to get a report from Republicans. And 435 members are going to have to make a decision on a very weighty issue based on a report that comes really through two or three staffers writing a report through each side. That’s problematic. But elections have consequences. And so would I expect there to be complaints from the Democrats if they were in the minority? Probably.”

-- FOR THE RECORD: It seems somewhat newsy that Republicans will write their own impeachment takeaway report.

BTW … 45 REPUBLICANS -- nearly a quarter of the House Republican Conference -- have access to the depositions, including many among the top ranks of the caucus.

THE FOLLOWING REPUBLICANS HAVE ACCESS to all of the closed depositions and hearings: House Minority Leader KEVIN MCCARTHY, MEADOWS, House Intelligence Chairman DEVIN NUNES (R-Calif.), Rep. JOHN RATCLIFFE (R-Texas), Rep. SCOTT PERRY (R-Pa.), ZELDIN and Rep. GREG PENCE (R-Ind.), the VP’s brother.

REMEMBERING ELIJAH CUMMINGS -- “Elijah Cummings to lie in state at Capitol,” by Sarah Ferris and John Bresnahan: “Congress on Thursday will bid goodbye to Rep. Elijah Cummings (D-Md.), the son of sharecroppers who rose to become one of the Democratic Party's most influential figures at a tumultuous time in American politics. The late Oversight Committee chairman — who represented his majority-black Baltimore district in the House for two decades — will become the first African American lawmaker to lie in state in the Capitol, an honor bestowed to only a few dozen statesmen, presidents and military leaders throughout U.S. history.

“Thousands of visitors are expected to stream through the Capitol on Thursday to pay their final respects to Cummings, who died Oct. 17 at age 68. Earlier in the day, Cumming's casket will lie in state about 75 feet away from a statute of another civil rights icon, Rosa Parks, and just steps away from the bust of the former Confederate president Jefferson Davis — a reminder of Washington's troubled history on race relations, which Cummings himself battled throughout his life.” POLITICO

SPEAKING AT CUMMINGS’ FUNERAL FRIDAY IN BALTIMORE: Barack Obama, Bill and Hillary Clinton, and Nancy Pelosi.

DAILY RUDY -- “Rudy Giuliani is looking for a defense attorney, sources say,” by CNN’s Erica Orden, Katelyn Polantz and Evan Perez: “Rudy Giuliani has been approaching defense attorneys for possible representation, according to three sources familiar with the matter. The move by Giuliani, who is President Donald Trump's personal attorney, is notable because last week he said he would not be seeking a new lawyer unless he felt one was needed. His previous lawyer, John Sale, was helping him deal with congressional inquiries.” CNN

IMPEACHMENT CLIP PACKET …

-- NYT: “Trump’s War on the ‘Deep State’ Turns Against Him,” by Peter Baker, Lara Jakes, Julian Barnes, Sharon LaFraniere and Edward Wong: “Nameless, faceless and voiceless, the C.I.A. officer who first triggered the greatest threat to President Trump’s tenure in office seemed to be practically the embodiment of the “deep state” that the president has long accused of trying to take him down.

“But over the last three weeks, the deep state has emerged from the shadows in the form of real live government officials, past and present, who have defied a White House attempt to block cooperation with House impeachment investigators and provided evidence that largely backs up the still-anonymous whistle-blower.” NYT

-- KYLE CHENEY, ANDREW DESIDERIO and WESLEY MORGAN: “Pentagon official testifies about withheld military aid to Ukraine”: “A Pentagon official who sought the release of U.S. military aid to Ukraine — withheld by the White House amid attempts to persuade Ukraine to investigate President Donald Trump’s political rivals — testified Wednesday to House impeachment investigators about her knowledge of the episode amid attempts by the Trump administration to block her appearance.

“Laura Cooper, the deputy assistant secretary of defense for Russia, Ukraine, and Eurasia, appeared despite an effort by the Pentagon to block her cooperation. … An official who works on the impeachment inquiry said Cooper testified for more than three hours behind closed doors under subpoena — a repeat of the tactic lawmakers have used to circumvent other attempts by the Trump administration to block witnesses from complying with interview requests.” POLITICO

-- CNN: “How two businessmen hustled to profit from access to Rudy Giuliani and the Trump administration,” by Katelyn Polantz, Scott Glover and Vicky Ward: “The pair raked in hundreds of thousands of dollars and jetted around the world touting their connections to Giuliani and the Trump administration while pushing for business and favors, even claiming to arrange a Fox News interview, right up until the day they were arrested for conspiracy and campaign-finance related charges.

“At one point, they pushed a Ukrainian businessman to pay them to bring Trump administration officials to Ukraine. At another time, they convinced a Florida-based businessman to loan them $100,000 so they could connect him with Giuliani and other prominent conservatives. And in a third instance, they attempted to influence the management board of a Ukrainian gas company.” CNN

FOR YOUR RADAR -- “North Korea urges U.S. to act wisely through year-end deadline,” by AP’s Kim Tong-Hyung in Seoul, South Korea: “North Korea on Thursday accused U.S. officials of maintaining hostility against Pyongyang despite a ‘special’ relationship between leader Kim Jong Un and President Donald Trump and urged Washington to act ‘wisely’ through the end of the year.

“The statement issued by Foreign Ministry adviser Kim Kye Gwan was clearly referring to an end-of-year deadline set by Kim Jong Un for the Trump administration to offer mutually acceptable terms for a deal to salvage their diplomacy.

“Nuclear negotiations between Washington and Pyongyang have faltered after the collapse of a February summit between Kim Jong Un and Trump where the U.S. side rejected North Korean demands for broad sanctions relief in exchange for a piecemeal deal toward partially surrendering its nuclear capabilities.” AP

JOHN BRESNAHAN: “Rep. Katie Hill investigated over allegations of improper relationship with staffer”: “The House Ethics Committee announced Wednesday it has launched an investigation into Democratic Rep. Katie Hill following allegations she engaged in an improper sexual relationship with a male congressional staffer.

“The California Democrat denied that allegation in a statement to POLITICO on Tuesday, and she blamed the controversy on an ‘abusive husband’ whom she is in the midst of divorcing.

“However, in a letter to her constituents sent out just before the Ethics Committee announcement, Hill admitted to having an ‘inappropriate’ relationship with a female campaign staffer during her run for Congress in 2018. Hill apologized for the relationship, which the freshman lawmaker said occurred ‘despite my better judgment.’

“‘During the final tumultuous years of my abusive marriage, I became involved in a relationship with someone on my campaign,’ Hill said in her letter. ‘I know that even a consensual relationship with a subordinate is inappropriate, but I still allowed it to happen despite my better judgment. For that I apologize. I wish nothing but the best for her and hope everyone respects her privacy in this difficult time.’” POLITICO

TRUMP’S THURSDAY -- The president will participate in a Diwali ceremonial lighting of the diya at 1:45 p.m. in the Oval Office. He will present the Presidential Medal of Freedom to auto-racing legend Roger Penske at 4:30 p.m. in the Oval Office.

JOSH GERSTEIN: “National Archives probes Wilbur Ross’ use of private email”

AP/KYIV: “Ukrainian leader felt Trump pressure before taking office”: “More than two months before the phone call that launched the impeachment inquiry into President Donald Trump, Ukraine’s newly elected leader was already worried about pressure from the U.S. president to investigate his Democratic rival Joe Biden.

“Volodymyr Zelenskiy gathered a small group of advisers on May 7 in Kyiv for a meeting that was supposed to be about his nation’s energy needs. Instead, the group spent most of the three-hour discussion talking about how to navigate the insistence from Trump and his personal lawyer, Rudy Giuliani, for a probe and how to avoid becoming entangled in the American elections, according to three people familiar with the details of the meeting.” AP

ICYMI -- “Giuliani associates plead not guilty in campaign finance case,” by Josh Gerstein: “Two associates of President Donald Trump’s personal lawyer Rudy Giuliani entered not guilty pleas Wednesday to a federal indictment accusing them of funneling hundreds of thousands of dollars in foreign money into U.S. elections, including a pro-Trump super PAC.

“The pleas came as the two men, Lev Parnas and Igor Fruman, made their first court appearance in Manhattan following their arrest earlier this month at Dulles Airport near Washington as they attempted to board a flight for Vienna.

“During the hearing, one of Parnas’ lawyers appeared to warn prosecutors that the case could be a challenging one for them because of complex issues of attorney-client privilege and even executive privilege, since Parnas claims to have been working with Giuliani as he worked for Trump.” POLITICO

-- NYT: “As Russian Money Poured Into Cannabis, Giuliani Allies Scrambled to Partake”

A message from Google: Find out where you can properly dispose of unused prescription drugs.

WHAT RUDY IS READING -- “Hunter Biden’s Name Was Used as Selling Point in Fraudulent Bond Scheme,” by WSJ’s Dave Michaels and Theo Francis: “Hunter Biden’s work in Ukraine and China has attracted criticism from President Trump and other Republicans. In an unrelated fraud case from last year, his name was invoked as a selling point in transactions that turned out to be fraudulent, although Mr. Biden‘s lawyer said his client knew nothing about it.

“The case involved a $60 million securities fraud based on bonds issued by an economic-development company affiliated with a Native American tribe in South Dakota, according to prosecutors’ statements in a federal trial in Manhattan last year. ...

“[One of the] alleged co-conspirators in the affair, which unfolded from 2014 and 2016, was Devon Archer, a longtime business partner of Mr. Biden, according to prosecutors. A consultant’s report aimed at potential investors listed Mr. Archer as chairman of the combined financial firm and Mr. Biden as its vice chairman, according to trial testimony. At the time Mr. Biden’s father, Joe Biden, was vice president.” WSJ

QUOTE DU JOUR: Sen. John Cornyn (R-Texas) in the Dallas Morning News: “If Turkey was planning on coming into northern Syria and trying to ethnically cleanse the Kurds, and U.S. troops were caught in the middle, I am not completely convinced that it was a bad idea to get them out of harm’s way.”

VALLEY TALK -- “Democrats torch Zuckerberg for 5 hours,” by Zachary Warmbrodt and Cristiano Lima

MEDIAWATCH -- “James Murdoch on ‘Succession,’ Pete Buttigieg and Climate Change,” by Variety’s Elaine Low: “At Vanity Fair’s New Establishment Summit, Murdoch gamely responded questions about his entertainment-viewing habits before more seriously discussing onstage his support of Democratic presidential candidate Pete Buttigieg, the potential to succeed Disney CEO Bob Iger and issues such as climate change and income inequality.

“When asked directly whether he watches right-leaning cable network Fox News, the youngest Murdoch replied, ‘Uh, no.’ He later added that he was ‘disappointed’ that Fox News anchor Shepard Smith had departed the network, and effectively attempted to distance himself from the influential cabler under his family’s control, pointing instead to his track record of news operations he has run, including Star in India and Sky News in the U.K. The media exec called opinion programming U.S. cable news not ‘terribly helpful,’ but also pinned some of the blame on ‘crazily damaging’ talk radio.” Variety
